title: 109_s942
content: The "Virginia Ridge and Valley Act of 2005" designates additional national forest system lands as wilderness in Virginia. The Act designates certain lands in the Jefferson National Forest in Virginia as wilderness areas, including Brush Mountain East Wilderness and additional acres in the forest. The Brush Mountain Wilderness comprises approximately 4,794 acres, the Raccoon Branch Wilderness comprises 4,223 acres, the Stone Mountain Wilderness comprises 3,270 acres, and the Jefferson National Forest contains approximately 8,470 acres designated as wilderness areas. The Hunting Camp Creek Wilderness comprises approximately 8,470 acres, the Garden Mountain Wilderness comprises 3,291 acres, the Lynn Camp Creek Wilderness comprises 3,226 acres, and certain lands in the Jefferson National Forest comprise approximately 5,476 acres designated as wilderness areas. The curr_chunk describes the incorporation of certain lands in the Jefferson National Forest into the Mountain Lake, Lewis Fork, and Little Wilson Creek Wilderness areas, totaling approximately 5,629 acres. The curr_chunk describes the incorporation of additional lands in the Jefferson National Forest into the Shawvers Run, Peters Mountain, and Kimberling Creek Wilderness areas, totaling approximately 4,271 acres. SEC. 3. Seng Mountain and Bear Creek Scenic Areas in Jefferson National Forest, Virginia. The National Forest System lands in Virginia are designated as National Scenic Areas, including Seng Mountain and Bear Creek in the Jefferson National Forest. Seng Mountain comprises approximately 6,455 acres, while Bear Creek comprises approximately 5,503 acres. The National Forest System lands in Virginia, including Seng Mountain and Bear Creek in the Jefferson National Forest, are designated as National Scenic Areas. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to file a map and boundary description of the scenic areas with specific committees in Congress, which will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The map and description will be available for public inspection in the Office of the Chief of the Forest Service. The National Scenic Areas in Virginia, including Seng Mountain and Bear Creek in the Jefferson National Forest, are established for protecting scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, wildlife habitat, old-growth forests, and recreation opportunities. The Secretary of Agriculture administers these areas in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. The Secretary of Agriculture shall develop a management plan for the National Scenic Areas in Virginia within two years of the enactment of this Act, consistent with applicable laws and regulations. The plan will further the purposes for which the scenic areas are established and will be developed as an amendment to the land and resource management plan for the Jefferson National Forest. After the enactment of the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974, no roads can be built in scenic areas, except for access to private lands. Timber harvest is prohibited in scenic areas, except for fire control and public safety. Motorized travel is not allowed. Motorized travel is generally not permitted in scenic areas, except for specific purposes authorized by the Secretary of Agriculture. Wildfires in the scenic area will be suppressed in a manner consistent with the section's purposes. Insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled in the scenic areas to maintain scenic quality and protect private lands. The Secretary of Agriculture administers scenic areas to maintain water quality and prohibits mining activities on federally owned lands within the areas. Additionally, there is a trail plan and development outlined in Section 4. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a trail plan for National Forest System lands to develop hiking, equestrian, and nonmotorized recreation trails. Within two years, a report on the trail plan implementation, including priority trails, will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary is authorized to develop trails for continuous connection. Authorized to develop trails for nonmotorized travel between County Route 650 and Forest Development Road 4018 in Smyth County, Virginia, as recorded on the map entitled "Seng Mountain and Raccoon Branch" dated March 23, 2005.
